articles.headline: Disappointed Supporters Question Obama
articles.snippet: In a live televised session, President Obama heard from several people who said they’d expected more from him.
articles.abstract: In a live televised session, President Obama heard from several people who said they’d expected more from him.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  It was billed as “Investing in America,” a live televised conversation on the state of the economy between President Obama and American workers, students, business people and retirees, a kind of Wall Street to Main Street reality check.

articles.headline: H.P. Settles Lawsuit Against Hurd
articles.snippet: Hewlett-Packard had sued Mark Hurd over his joining Oracle. The terms of the settlement were not disclosed, but H.P. did modify his separation agreement.
articles.abstract: Hewlett-Packard had sued Mark Hurd over his joining Oracle. The terms of the settlement were not disclosed, but H.P. did modify his separation agreement.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  A fierce and public feud between Oracle and Hewlett-Packard, two of the world’s largest technology companies, has ended after all of two weeks.
articles.byline: By Ashlee Vance and Verne G. Kopytoff

articles.headline: Oil Company Fined in Royalty Case
articles.snippet: A judge ordered Kerr-McGee Oil and Gas to pay millions in penalties, including some to a whistle-blower who said the company cheated the government out of royalties.
articles.abstract: A judge ordered Kerr-McGee Oil and Gas to pay millions in penalties, including some to a whistle-blower who said the company cheated the government out of royalties.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Nearly seven years after a government auditor charged that an oil company had cheated the government out of millions of dollars in royalties, a federal judge has ordered the company to pay nearly $23 million in penalties  including $5.7 million to the auditor who uncovered the problem.

articles.headline: Recession May Be Over, but Joblessness Remains
articles.snippet: The United States economy has lost more jobs than it has added since the recovery began over a year ago.
articles.abstract: The United States economy has lost more jobs than it has added since the recovery began over a year ago.
articles.lead_paragraph: The United States economy has lost more jobs than it has added since the recovery began over a year ago.

articles.headline: Ex-Physicist Leads Flash Crash Inquiry
articles.snippet: The leader of the team investigating the May 6 crash promises his report will clearly demonstrate how market conditions and events led to extreme price moves.
articles.abstract: The leader of the team investigating the May 6 crash promises his report will clearly demonstrate how market conditions and events led to extreme price moves.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As a doctoral candidate in physics at Princeton two decades ago, Gregg E. Berman spent a year and a half in a laboratory searching through subatomic data for an elusive particle called the heavy neutrino.

articles.headline: Donor Names Remain Secret as Rules Shift
articles.snippet: Nonprofit groups, which are not allowed to be primarily political, are big players in this year’s election, and their donors can usually remain anonymous.
articles.abstract: Nonprofit groups, which are not allowed to be primarily political, are big players in this year’s election, and their donors can usually remain anonymous.
articles.lead_paragraph: Crossroads Grassroots Policy Strategies would certainly seem to the casual observer to be a political organization: Karl Rove, a political adviser to President George W. Bush, helped raise money for it; the group is run by a cadre of experienced political hands; it has spent millions of dollars on television commercials attacking Democrats in key Senate races across the country.
articles.byline: By Michael Luo and Stephanie Strom

articles.headline: Afghan Boys Are Prized, So Girls Live the Part
articles.snippet: Under pressure to have sons, some families dress their girls as boys.
articles.abstract: Under pressure to have sons, some families dress their girls as boys.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan  Six-year-old Mehran Rafaat is like many girls her age. She likes to be the center of attention. She is often frustrated when things do not go her way. Like her three older sisters, she is eager to discover the world outside the family’s apartment in their middle-class neighborhood of Kabul.

articles.headline: Mexico Paper, a Drug War Victim, Calls for a Voice
articles.snippet: After the killing of an El Diario intern, an editorial asked organized crime leaders to tell the paper what it should publish.
articles.abstract: After the killing of an El Diario intern, an editorial asked organized crime leaders to tell the paper what it should publish.
articles.lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY  It was by turns defiant and deferential, part plea and part plaint, a message as much to the drug gangs with a firm grip on Ciudad Juárez, the bloodiest city in Mexico’s drug battles, as to the authorities and their perceived helplessness.

articles.headline: Seeking Kashmir Peace, India Feels Anger of Residents
articles.snippet: After more than 100 days of deadly protests in Kashmir, India this week sent the equivalent of a peace delegation.
articles.abstract: After more than 100 days of deadly protests in Kashmir, India this week sent the equivalent of a peace delegation.
articles.lead_paragraph: SRINAGAR, Kashmir  The Indian members of Parliament left their shoes on the floor beneath a wall covered in photographs of slain Kashmiris. The five men sat cross-legged on the floor of the headquarters of the Jammu Kashmir Liberation Front, staring into a throng of television cameras as they delivered a carefully scripted message of reconciliation.
